Tulsa Facility

Tulsa, Oklahoma







EXECUTIVE SUMMARY FOR THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN 



Introduction 



The Chemtrade Tulsa Plant has been operating at 5201 W. 21st Street in Tulsa Oklahoma since the early 1910's. In 1998, the site expanded its operations to construct the 20% Oleum process, which allows the site to manufacture semi-conductor grade sulfuric acid. We pro-actively manage site operational safety, while minimizing environmental, health, and security risks.  This site is independently certified as an RC 14001:2008 and ISO 14001:2008 facility, and has been since 2010.  We owe our operational success to sound business practices which strive to put operational safety, health, security and environmental impact considerations as a key aspect of all business decisions.  This commitment is found in the Chemtrade Responsible Care Policy and in the Chemtrade Environmental Health and Safety Policy, and is the key to our business success.  





Chemtrade Responsible Care Policy



CHEMTRADE is committed to Responsible Care® as the key to our business success. Responsible Care is our commitment to do and be seen as doing the "right thing". The Responsible Care principles form the basis of our business philosophy towards societal, economic, and environmental sustainability. Chemtrade applies these principles to strive for continual improvement of our performance in the areas of Environmental Management, Safety and Health Protection, Safe Transportation, Process Safety Management, and Security of our processes, products, services and activities. Chemtrade applies the following principles in its implementation of the Responsible Care ethic: 



1. Promoting awareness of Responsible Care and inspiring our employees and others to adhere to these principles to instill a Responsible Care culture throughout our organization. 



2. Respecting our employees and all other stakeholders and encouraging them to work together towards con

tinuous improvement of our business processes to ensure that our products are manufactured safely and our products and raw materials are transported, used, and disposed or recycled safely during their life cycles in order to protect the safety, health, and security of our employees and stakeholders. 



3. Designing, developing, maintaining and operating business processes focused on: safer products and processes; improved safety, security and health of individuals; and reducing our impact on the environment by responsible methods of resource conservation, pollution prevention and energy efficiency. 



4. Being proactive in taking preventative actions to identify, reduce and manage our risks and to protect the safety, health, and security of our employees and all other stakeholders. 



5. Communicating our Responsible Care performance to the public and holding ourselves accountable to our stakeholders, who have the right to understand the risks and benefits of what we do and to have their input heard regarding our products, services, activities and operations. 



6. Supporting education and research on environmental, safety and health effects and security of our products and processes that may improve people's lives and striving to meet or exceed expectations for social responsibility and community involvement; and 



7. Cooperatively participating in the public policy process for effective laws and standards that safeguard the community, workplace and environment and meeting or exceeding them in letter and spirit. 



Chemtrade Environmental, Safety, and Health Policy



CHEMTRADE will demonstrate our commitment to our employees, customers, supply chain partners, the public, and other stakeholders by working on continual improvement in the areas of Environmental Management, Safety and Health Protection, Safe Transportation, Process Safety Management, and Security of our processes, products, services and activities by: 

1. Maintaining a management system that d

rives the continual improvement of our performance in these areas. 

2. Meeting and striving to exceed applicable laws, regulations or other requirements. 

3. Developing appropriate site procedures and employee training programs to promote a safe, healthy, and secure workplace and the protection of the environment. 

4. Providing information, guidance and training to our employees, customers, supply chain partners, the public, and other stakeholders in the safe and responsible use, handling and disposal of our products. 

5. Maintaining appropriate internal emergency response capabilities and coordinating with external emergency responders to effectively respond to situations that involve our products or that may impact our employees and other stakeholders. 

6. Undertaking periodic reviews of our assets, operations and activities to measure the organization's performance and compliance with this policy, applicable laws, and other requirements. 

7. Setting objectives and targets intended to improve the organization's performance and to drive continuous improvement. 

8. Applying appropriate process safety and risk management principles to all manufacturing processes. 

9. Adhering to basic security measures to protect our employees and other stakeholders including protection of products and other assets; and 

10. Maintaining procedures that promote the safe storage and transportation of our raw materials and products. 





Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios



As specified under ?68.25, the facility has considered the worst case scenario to be a catastrophic failure of the site's 318 ton 20% oleum storage tank and subsequent pooling of the liquid into the site's diked concrete containment passive mitigation system. Such a scenario is highly unlikely to occur; however, using the EPA Offsite Consequence Analysis methods, the distance to concentration levels of <0.01 mg/L would be 6.2 miles. The Tulsa Plant has numerous engineering, operational, and admin

istrative controls to prevent such a release and manage the off-site consequences. The alternative case scenario which the site considered would be the development of a hole within the oleum storage tank, which would be 2.5 cm in diameter. This event would cause an offsite consequence at a distance of 3.1 miles. These distances were calculated by the EPA RMP*Comp Program.  The Tulsa site has numerous mitigation measures in place to prevent such a release and minimize the consequences of a release, in the unlikely event of such an occurrence. 



Prevention Program



The Tulsa facility has been operating under the principles of Process Safety Management for the RMP Covered Process since the process was constructed in 1998. In addition, the Tulsa facility has incorporated the principles of Process Safety Management into its operation of other, non-covered processes, since 2005. Although this facility is not regulated under the OSHA PSM Standard, our commitment to "Do the Right Thing" means that we apply appropriate process safety and risk management principles to all manufacturing processes, and use various resources to evaluate and follow the chemical manufacturing industries' best practices. 



The Oleum Manufacturing process is continuously monitored, 24-7, by operators who have been trained and certified in accordance with the RMP rule.  The site has installed redundant engineering controls, including interlocks and fail-safe technology where feasible to reduce risk.  The site records levels, flows, and pressures within the process. Administrative controls such as audible and visual alarms are used to identify recorded values which fall outside of acceptable operational control parameters, so that problems with the operation of the system can be quickly identified and mitigated.  Site operators take visual readings throughout the production area at 1 hour intervals in order to monitor conditions within the plant and record operational data. Operational controls

such as safe work practices, safe work permitting, and operational procedures assist the site in keeping operations safe for employees and stakeholders. 



Five Year Accident History



This site has experienced no Reportable Quantity releases within the last 5 years. This site has experienced no recordable injuries associated with the operation of the Oleum Process within the last 5 years.  This site has experienced a minor release from the Oleum process which caused a contractor working on-site to need first aid treatment and has experienced one first - aid injury of a Chemtrade employee who was engaged in loading Oleum into a Hazmat Transportation Trailer.  



Emergency Response Program



This site conducts emergency response in accordance with a written Emergency Response Program (ERP).  The site's ERP directs the site's on-site response activities under the direction of an Incident Commander. All site employees are trained in the site's Emergency Response Program, and are trained, at a minimum, to the Hazardous Materials Technician level of training.  Site supervisors and A-Operators are trained to the Hazardous Materials Incident Commander level of training. A representative from the Chemtrade Tulsa site attends in community emergency planning events and Local Emergency Planning Committee meetings with the Tulsa County LEPC.  We maintain an ongoing dialogue with Tulsa County Emergency Management services, and Berryhill Fire Department.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



This site is continuously working to improve site safety conditions. The site is currently undergoing the following improvement projects:



1.    This site will conduct an on-site Fall Prevention Evaluation, and improve platforms, guardrails, and anchorages as needed to prevent fall injuries. 

2.    The site will continue to train all new employees and existing employees in Emergency Response and HAZWOPER, as needed for their job duties. 

3.    The site is continuing a process to upgrade it

s on-site rail system, which includes monthly track inspections and repairs. 

4.    The site has implemented a maintenance work order program which will assist the site in identifying critical HSE equipment in order to prioritize maintenance activities within the plant.
